editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.p: A comedy, as it was acted by her majesty's servants, at the private house in Drury lane.
London, printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke. 1637.

div.head: To the right honourable Richard lord Lovelace of Hurley.
div.p:
I cannot want encouragement to present a poem to your lordship, while you possess so noble a breast, in which so many seeds of honour, to the example and glory of your name obtained, before your years a happy maturity. This comedy fortunate in the scene, and one that may challenge a place in the first form of the author's compositions, most humbly addresseth itself to your honour, if it meet your
gracious acceptance, and that you repent not to be a patron, your lordships will only crowns the imagination, and for ever by this favour oblige,

closer.signed: My lord the most humble services of your honourer, James Shirley.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.l: Be patient madam, you may have your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: 'Tis that I came to town for, I would not
Endure again the country conversation,
To be the lady of six shires! the men
So near the primitive making, they retain
A sense of nothing but the earth, their brains
And barren heads standing as much in want
Of ploughing as their ground, to hear a fellow
Make himself merry and his horse with whistling
Sellinger's round, to observe with what solemnity
They keep their wakes, and throw for pewter candlesticks,
How they become the morris, which whose bells
They ring all into Whitsun ales, and sweat,
Through twenty scarves and napkins, till the hobby-horse
Tire, and the maid marrian dissolved to a jelly,
Be kept for spoon meat.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: These with your pardon are no argument
To make the country life appear so hateful,
At least to your particular, who enjoyed
A blessing in that calm; would you be pleased
To think so, and the pleasure of a kingdom,
While your own will commanded what should move
Delights, your husband's love and power joined
To give your life more harmony ▪ you lived there,
Secure, and innocent, beloved of all,
Praised for your hospitality, and prayed for ▪
you might be envied, but malice knew
Not where you dwelled, I would not prophecy
But leave to your own apprehension
What may succeed your change.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You do imagine,
No doubt, you have talked wisely, and confuted,
London passed all defence, your master should
Do well to send you back into the country,
With title of superintendent bailiff.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: How madam.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Even so sir.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: I am a gentleman though now your servant.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: A country gentleman,
By your affection to converse with stable,
His tenants will advance you wit, and plump it so
With beef and bag-pudding.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: You may say your pleasure,
It becomes not me dispute.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Complain to the lord of the soil your master.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: You're a woman of an ungoverned passion, and I pity you.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How how? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: Nothing sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Angry sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I am angry with myself,
To be so miserably restrained in things,
Wherein it doth concern your love and honour
To see me satisfied.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: In what Aretina?
Dost thou accuse me? have I not obeyed
All thy desires, against mine own opinion,
Quit the country, and removed the hope
Of our return, by sale of that fair lordship
We lived in, changed a calm and retire life
For this wild town, composed of noise and charge.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What charge more than is necessary,
For a lady of my birth and education ▪

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I am not ignorant, how much nobility
flows in your blood, your kinsmen great and powerful,
It ▪ h state, but with this lose not your memory
Of being my wife, I shall be studious
Madam to give the dignity of your birth
All the best ornaments which become my fortune
But would not flatter it, to ruin both,
And be the fable of the town, to teach
Other men loss of wit by mine, employed
To serve your vast expenses.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Am I then
Brought in the balance? so sir.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Though you weigh
Me in a partial scale my heart is honest,
And must take liberty to think you have
Obeyed no modest counsel to effect,
Nay study ways of pride and costly ceremony,
Your change of gaudy furniture and pictures
Of this Italian master, and that Dutchman's,
Your mighty looking-glasses like artillery;
Brought whom on engines, the superfluous plate,
Antic and novel, vanities of tires,
Fourscore pound suppers for my lord your kinsman,
Banquets for tother lady, aunt, and cozens,
And perfumes that exceed all train of servants,
To stifle us at home and show abroad
More motley than the French, or the Venetian ▪
About your coach whose rude postilion
Must pester every narrow lane, till passengers
And tradesmen curse your choking up their stalls;
And common cries pursue your ladyship,
For hindering o'their market.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Have you done sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I could accuse the gaiety of your wardrobe,
And prodigal embroideries under which
Rich satins, plushes, cloth of silver, dare
Not show their own complexions, your jewels
Able to burn out the spectators eyes,
And show like bonfires on you by the tapers,
Something might here be spared, which safely of
Your birth and honour, since the truest wealth,
Shines from the soul, and draws up just admirers,
I could urge something more:

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Pray do I like
Your homily of thrift.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I could wish madam
You would not game so much.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: A gamester too?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: But are not come to that repentance yet,
Should teach you skill enough to raise your profit,
You look not through the subtlety of cards,
And mysteries of dice, nor can you save
Charge with the box, buy petticoats and purls,
And keep your family by the precious income,
Nor do I wish you should, my poorest servant
Shall not upbraid my tables, nor his hire
Purchased beneath my honour, you make play
Not a pastime but a tyranny, and vex
Yourself and my estate by't.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Good, proceed.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Another game you have, which consumes more
Your fame than purse, you revels in the night,
Your meetings called the ball, to which appear,
As to the court of pleasure, all your gallants,
And ladies thither bound by a subpoena
Of Venus, and small Cupid's high displeasure,
'Tis but the family of love translated
Into more costly sin, there was a play on't,
And had the poet not been bribed to a modest
Expression of your antic gambols, in't,
Some darks had been discovered, and the deeds too,
In time he may repent and make some blush.
To see the second part danced on the stage;
My thoughts acquit you for dishonouring me
By any foul act, but the virtuous know,
'Tis not enough to clear ourselves, but the
Suspicions of our shame.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Have you concluded
Your lecture?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I ha' done, and howsoever
My language my appear to you, it carries
No other than my fair and just intent
To your delights without curb to their modest,
And noble freedom.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I'll not be so tedious,
In my reply, but without art or elegance,
Assure you I keep still my first opinion,
and though you veil, your avaricious meaning
With handsome names of modesty, and thrift,
I find you would entrench and wound the liberty
I was born with, were my desires unprivileged
By example, while my judgement thought 'em fit,
You ought not to oppose, but when the practice
And tract of every honourable lady,
Authorize me, I take it great injustice,
To have my pleasures circumscribed, and taught me,
A narrow minded husband is a thief
To his own fame, and his preferment too,
He shuts his parts and fortunes from the world,
While from the popular vote and knowledge men
Rise to employment in the state.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I have
No great ambition to buy preferment
At so dear rate.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Nor I to sell my honour,
By living poor and sparingly, I was not
Bred in that ebb of fortune, and my fate
Shall not compel me to't.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I know not madam,
But you pursue these ways.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What ways?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: In the strict sense of honesty I dare
Make oath, they are innocent.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Do not divert,
By busy troubling of your brain, those thoughts
That should preserve 'em.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How was that?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: 'Tis English.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: But carries some unkind sense.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Good morrow my sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Decoy welcome, this visit is a favour.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Alas sweet madam, I cannot stay, I came
But to present my service to your ladyship;
I could not pass by your door, but I must take
The boldness to tender my respects.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You oblige me madam, but I must
Not dispense so with your absence.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Alas, the coach madam stays for me at the door.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Thou shalt command mine, prithee sweet Decoy.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I would wait on you madam, but I have many
visits to make this morning I beseech.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: So you will promise to dine with me.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I shall
Present a guest.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Why then good morrow madam.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: A happy day shine on your ladyship. Exit.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What's your news sir?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Madam two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What gentlemen? Have they no names.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: They are
The gentleman with his own head of hair,
Whom you commended for his horsemanship
In hide park, and becoming the saddle
The tother day.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What circumstance is this,
To know him by.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: His names at my tongue's end,
He liked the fashion of your pearl chain madam,
And borrowed it for his jeweller to take
A copy by it.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What cheating gallants this?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: That never walks without a lady's busk,
And plays with fans Mr. Alexander Kickshaw,
I thought I should remember him.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What's the other?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: What an unlucky memory I have?
The gallant that still danceth in the street,
And wears a gross of ribbon in his hat,
That carries oringado in his pocket,
And sugarplumbs to sweeten his discourse,
That studies compliment, defies all wit
On black, and censures plays that are not bawdy,
Mr. John Littleworth.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: They are welcome, but
Pray entertain them a small time, lest I
Be unprovided.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Did they ask for me?

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: It matters not, they must be welcome.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Fie, how's this hair disordered? here's a curl,
Straddle most impiously, I must to my closet. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Wait on 'em: my lady will return again,
I have to such a height fulfilled her humour,
All applications dangerous, these gallants
Must be received or she will fall into
A tempest, and the house be shaken with names
Of all her kindred, 'tis a servitude,
I may in time shake off.

sp.speaker: Al. Lit.
sp.l: Save you sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Save you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What day is it abroad?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: The morning rises from your lady's eye,
If she look clear, we take the happy omen
Of a fair day.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: She'll instantly appear,
To the discredit of your compliment,
But you express your wit thus.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And you modesty,
Not to affect the praises of your own.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Leaving this subject, what games now on foot ▪
What exercise carries the general vote?
O'th' town now nothing moves without your knowledge,

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: The cocking now has all the noise, I'll have
A hundred pieces of one battle, o,
These birds of Mars!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Venus is Mars his bird too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why and the pretty doves are Venusses,
To show that kisses draw the chariot.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: I am for that skirmish.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: When shall we have
More booths and bagpipes upon Bansted downs,
No mighty race is expected, but my lady returns.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Fair morning to you gentlemen,
You went not late to bed by your early visit,
You do me honour.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: It becomes our service.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What news abroad? you hold precious intelligence.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: All tongues are so much busy with your praise,
They have not time to frame other discourse,
Will please you madam? taste a sugar-plum.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What does the goldsmith think the pearl is worth.
You borrowed of my lady?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Tis a rich one.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: She has many other toys whose fashion you,
Will like extremely, you have no intention
To buy any of her jewels.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Understand me.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You had rather sell perhaps, but leaving this,
I hope you'll dine with us.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I came a purpose.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: And where were you last night?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I madam? where
I slept not, it had been sin where so much
Delight and beauty was to keep me waking,
There is a lady madam will be worth
Your free society, my conversation
Ne'er knew so elegant and brave a soul,
With most incomparable flesh and blood,
So spirited, so courtly speaks the languages,
Sings, dances, plays o'th lute to admiration,
Is fair and paints not, games too, keeps a table,
And talks most witty satire, has a wit
Of a clean Mercury.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Is she married?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: A virgin?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: What a widow? something.
Of this wide commendation might have been
Excused, this such a prodigy?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Repent
Before I name her, she did never see
Yet full sixteen, an age in the opinion
Of wise men not contemptible, she has
Mourned out her year too for the honest knight
That had compassion of her youth, and died
So timely, such a widow is not common,
And now she shines more fresh and tempting
Then any natural virgin.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What's her name?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: She was christened Celestina, by her husband
The lady Bellamour, this ring was hers.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You borrowed it to copy out the posy.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Are they not pretty rubies? 'twas a grace
She was pleased to show me, that I might have one
Made of the same fashion, for I love
All pretty forms.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: And is she glorious?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: She is full of jewels madam, but I am
Most taken with the bravery of her mind,
Although her garments have all grace and ornament.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You have been high in praises.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I come short,
No flattery can reach her.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Now my lady
Is troubled as she feared to be eclipsed,
this news will cost me somewhat.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You deserve
Her favour for this noble character.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And I possess it by my stars benevolence.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You must bring us acquainted.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I pray do sir.
I long to see her too, madam I have
Thought upon't and corrected my opinion,
Pursue what ways of pleasure your desires
Incline you too, not only with my state,
But with my person I will follow you,
I see the folly of my thrift, and will
Repent in sack and prodigality
To your own hearts content.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: But do not mock.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Take me to your embraces gentlemen
And tutor me.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: And will you kiss the ladies?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: And sing and dance, I long to see this beauty,
I wood fain lose a hundred pounds at dice now,
Thou shalt have another gown and petticoat,
Tomorrow will you sell my running horses?
We have no Greek wine in the house I think,
Pray send one of our footmen to the merchant,
And throw the hogsheads of march-beer into
The kennel, to make room for sacks and claret,
What think you to be drunk yet before dinner?
We will have constant music and maintain
Them and their fiddles in fantastic liveries,
I'll tune my voice to catches, I must have
My dining room enlarged to invite ambassadors,
We'll feast the parish in the fields, and teach
The military men new discipline,
Who shall charge all their new artillery
With oranges and lemons, boy to play
All dinner upon our capons.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: He's exalted.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I will do any thing to please my lady,
Let that suffice and kiss oath same condition,
I am converted, do not you dispute
But patiently allow the miracle. Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I am glad to hear you sir in so good tune.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Madam the painter.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I am to sit this morning.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Do, while I give new directions to my steward.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: With your favour we'll wait on you, sitting's but
A melancholy exercise without
Some company to discourse ▪

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: It does conclude
A lady's morning work, we rise, make fine,
Sit for our picture, and 'tis time to dine.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Praying's forgotten.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Tis out of fashion. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Fie, what an air this room has.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: 'Tis presumed.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: With some cheap sluff is it your wisdom's thrift
To infect my nostrils thus? Or is't to favour
The gout in your worship's hand? You are afraid
To exercise your pen in your account book?
Or do you doubt my credit to discharge
Your bills.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Madam, I hope you have not found
My duty with the guilt of sloth or jealousy,
Unapt to your command.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You can extenuate
Your faults with language sir, but I expect
To be obeyed; what hangings have we here?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: They are arras madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Impudence I know't,
I will have fresher and more rich, not wrought
With faces that may scandalize a christian
With Jewish storeys stuffed with corn and camels,
You had best wrap all my chambers in wild Irish,
And make a nursery of monsters here,
To fright the ladies comes to visit me.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Madam I hope.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I say I will have other,
Good master steward of a finer loom,
Some silk and silver if your worship please,
To let me be at so much cost I'll have
Storeys to sit the seasons of the year,
And change as often as I please.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: You shall madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am bound to your consent forsooth, and is
My coach brought home?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: This morning I expect it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: The inside as I gave direction,
of crimson plush.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Of crimson camel plush.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Ten thousand moths consum't, shall I ride through
The streets in penance wrapped up round in hair cloth,
Sel't to an alderman, 'twill serve his wife
To go a feasting to their country house,
Or fetch a merchant's nurse child, and come home
Laden with fruit and cheese cakes; I despise it.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: The nails adorn it madam, set in method
And pretty forms.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But single guilt I warrant.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: No madam:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Another solecism, o fie,
This fellow will bring me to a consumption
With fretting at his ignorance, some lady
Had rather never pray, than go to church in't;
The nails not double guilt? to market wilt,
'Twill hackney out to Mile-end, or convey
Your city tumblers to be drunk with cream
And prunes at Islington.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Good madam hear me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'll rather be beholding to my aunt
The countess for her mourning coach, then be
Disparaged so, shall any juggling tradesman
Be at charge to shoe his running horse with gold,
And shall my coach nails be but single guilt?
How dare these knaves abuse me so?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Vouchsafe
To hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is my sedan yet finished?
And liveries for my men-mules according
As I gave charge.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Yes madam it is finished,
But without tilting plumes at the four corners,
The scarlet's pure, but not embroidered.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What mischief were it to your conscience
Were my coach lined with tissue, and my harness
Covered with needlework? if my sedan
Had all the story of the prodigal,
Embroidered with pearl.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Alas good madam,
I know 'tis your own cost, I am but your steward,
And would discharge my duty the best way,
You have been pleased to hear me, 'tis not for
My profit, that I manage your estate,
And save expense, but for your honour madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How sir, my honour?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Though you hear it not
Men's tongues are liberal in your character,
Since you began to live thus high, I know
Your fame is precious to you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I were best
Make you my governor; audacious varlet,
How dare you interpose your doting counsel?
Mind your affairs with more obedience,
Or I shall ease you of an office sir,
Must I be limited to please your honour?
Or for the vulgar breath confine my pleasures,
I will pursue 'em in what shapes I fancy,
Here, and abroad, my entertainments shall
Be oftener, and more rich, who shall control me?
I live i'th strand, whether few ladies come
To live, and purchase, more than fame, I will
Be hospitable then, and spare no cost
That may engage all generous report
To trumpet forth my bounty and my bravery,
Till the court envy, and remove, I'll have
My house the academy of wits, who shall
Exalt with rich sack, and sturgeon,
Write panegyrics of my feasts, and praise
The method of my witty superfluities,
The horses shall be taught with frequent waiting
Upon my gates, to stop in their career
Towards Charing-cross, spite of the coachman's fury.
And not a tilter, but shall strike his plume,
When he fails by my window, my balcony
Shall be the courtier's idol, and more gazed at,
Than all the pageantry at temple bar,
By country clients.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Sure my lady's mad.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Take that for your ill manners.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Thank you madam,
I would there were less quicksilver in your fingers. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There's more than simple honesty in a servant
Required to his full duty, none should dare,
But with a look, much less a saucy language
Check at their mistress pleasure, I'm resolved
To pay for some delight, my estate will bear it,
I'll rein it shorter when I please.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: A gentleman
Desires to speak with your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: His name?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: He says you know him not, he seems to be
Of quality.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Admit him. Sir with me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Madam I know not, how you may receive
This boldness from me, but my fair intents
Known, will incline you to be charitable.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No doubt sir.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: He must live obscurely madam,
That hath not heard what virtues you possess,
And I a poor admirer of your fame,
Am come to kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That all your business?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Though it were worth much travel, I have more
In my ambition.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Speak it freely sir.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You are a widow.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And I a bachelor.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You come a-wooing sir, and would perhaps
Show me a way to reconcile these two.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And bless my stars for such a happiness.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I like you sir the better, that you do not
Wander about, but shoot home to the meaning,
'Tis a confidence will make a man
Know sooner what to trust to, but I never
Saw you before, and I believe you come not
With hope to find me desperate upon marriage,
If maids out of their ignorance of what
Men, are refuse these offers, widows may
Out of their knowledge be allowed some coyness,
And yet I know not how much happiness
A peremptory answer may deprive me of,
You may be some young lord, and though I see not
Your footmen and your groom, they may not be
Far off in conference with your horse, please you
To instruct me with your title, against which
I would not willingly offend.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am
A gentleman, my name is Hairecut madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sweet Mr. Hairecut, are you a courtier?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Yes

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I did think so by your confidence,
Not to detain you sir with circumstance,
I was not so unhappy in my husband
But that 'tis possible i may be a wife
Again, but i must tell you, he that wins
My affection shall deserve me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I will hope
If you can love, i sha'not present madam
An object to displease you in my person,
And when time, and your patience shall possess you
With further knowledge of me, and the truth
Of my devotion, you will not repent
The offer of my service.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You say well.
How long do you imagine you can love sir?
Is it a quotidian, or will it hold
But every other day?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You are pleasant madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Dost take you with a burning at the first,
Or with a cold fit, for you gentlemen
Have both your summer, and your winter service.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am ignorant what you mean, but i shall never
Be cold in my affection to such beauty.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And 'twill be somewhat long ere i be warm in't.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: If you vouchsafe me so much honour madam,
That i may wait on you sometimes, i sha'not
Despair to see a change.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But now i know
Your mind, you shall not need to tell it, when
You come again, i shall remember it.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You make me fortunate. Enter steward.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Madam your kinswomen
The lady novice and her sister are
New lighted from their coach.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I did expect 'em,
They partly are my pupils, I'll attend 'em.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Madam I have been too great a trespasser
Upon your patience, I'll take my leave,
You have affairs, and I have some employment
Calls me to court, I shall present again
A servant to you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir you may present,Exit. Ha.
But not give fire I hope, now to the ladies
This recreation's passed, the next must be
to read to them some court philosophy. Exeunt.

div.head: The second act.
div.l: 'Tis a strange humour I have undertaken
To dance, and play, and spend as fast as she does,
But I am resolved, it may do good upon her,
And fright her into thrift, nay I'll endeavour
To make her jealous too, if this do not
Allay her gambolling, she's passed a woman
And only a miracle must tame her.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: 'Tis Mr. Frederick my lady's nephew.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What of him?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Is come from the university.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: By whose directions?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: It seems my ladies.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Let me speak with him
Before he see his aunt, I do not like it.
Mr. Frederick welcome I expected not
So soon your presence, what's the hasty cause?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: These letters from my tutor will acquaint you.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Welcome home sweet Mr. Frederick.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Where's my aunt?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: She's busy about her painting, in her closet,
The outlandish man of art, is copying out
Her countenance.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: She is sitting for her picture.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Yes sir, and when 'tis drawn, she will be hanged
Next the French Cardinal in the dining room,
But when she hears you're come, she will dismiss
The Belgic gentleman to entertain
Your worship.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Change of air has made you witty.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your tutor gives you a handsome character
Frederick, and is sorry your aunt's pleasure
Commands you from your studies, but I hope
You have no quarrel to the liberal arts,
Learning is an addition beyond
Nobility of birth, honour of blood
Without the ornament of knowledge is
A glorious ignorance.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I never knew more sweet and happy hours
than I employed upon my books, I heard
A part of my philosophy, and was so
Delighted with the harmony of nature,
I could have wasted my whole life upon't.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: 'Tis pity a rash indulgence should corrupt
So fair a genius, she's here, I'll observe.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: My most loved aunt.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Support me, i shall faint.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: What ails your ladyship?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Is that Frederick,
In black.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Yes madam, but the doublets satin.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: The boy's undone.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Madam you appear troubled.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Have i not cause? Was not i trusted with
Thy education boy, and have they sent thee
Home like a very scholar.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: 'Twas ill done
Howe'er they used him in the university,
To send him to his friends thus.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why sir, black
(I or 'tis the colour that offends your eyesight)
Is not within my reading any blemish,
Sables are no disgrace in heraldry.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: 'Tis coming from the college thus, that makes it
Dishonourable, while you wore it for
Your father, it was commendable, or were
Your aunt dead, you might mourn and justify.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What luck i did not send him into France,
They would have given him generous education,
Taught him another garb to wear his lock,
And shape, as gawdy as the summer, how
To dance, and wag his feather ala mode,
To compliment, and cringe, to talk not modestly
Like i forsooth, and no forsooth, to blush
And look so like a chaplain, there he might
Have learned a brazen confidence, and observed
So well the custom of the country, that
He might by this time have invented fashions
For us, and been a benefit to the kingdom
Preserved our tailors in their wits, and saved
The charge of sending into foreign courts
For pride and antic fashions, observe,
In what a posture he does hold his hat now.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Madam with your pardon, you have practised
Another dialect then was taught me when
I was commended to your care and breeding,
I understand not this, Latin or Greek
Are more familiar to my apprehension,
Logic was not so hard in my first lectures
As your strange language.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Some strong waters, o!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Comfits will be as comfortable to your stomach madam.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I fear he's spoilt forever, he did name
Logic, and may for ought I know be gone
So far to understand it, I did always
Suspect they would corrupt him in the college,
Will your Greek saws and sentences discharge
The mercer, or is latin a fit language
To court a mistress in? Mr. Alexander
If you have any charity, let me
Commend him to your breeding, I suspect
I must employ my doctor first, to purge.
The university that lies in's head
It alters his complexion.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: If you dare
Trust me to serve him.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Mr. Littleworth
Be you joined in commission.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: I will teach him
Postures and rudiments.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I have no patience
To see him in this shape, it turns my stomach,
When he has cast his academic skin
He shall be yours, I am bound in conscience
To see him bred, his own state shall maintain
The charge, while he's my ward, come hither sir.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What does my aunt mean to do with me?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: To make you a fine gentleman, and translate you
Out of your learned language sir, into
The present Goth and Vandal, which is French.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Into what mischief will this humour ebb?
She will undo the boy, I see him ruined,
My patience is not manly, but I must
Use stratagem to reduce her, open ways
Give me no hope. Exit.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: You shall be obeyed madam. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Mr. steward, are you sure we do not dream?
Was't not my aunt you talked to.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: One that loves you
Dear as her life, these clothes do not become you,
You must have better sir.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: These are not old.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: More suitable to the town and time, we keep
No lent here, nor is't my lady's pleasure you
Should fast from any thing you have a mind to,
Unless it be your learning ▪ which she would have you
Forget with all convenient speed that may be,
For the credit of your noble family,
The case is altered since we lived i'th country,
We do not invite the poor o'th parish
To dinner, keep a table for the tenants,
Our kitchen does not smell of beef, the cellar
Defies the price of malt and hops, the footmen
And coachdrivers may be drunk like gentlemen
With wine, nor will three fiddlers upon holidays
With aid of bag pipes, that called in the country
To dance, and plough the hall up with their hobnails,
Now make my lady merry, we do feed
Like princes, and feast nothing but princes,
And are these robes fit to be seen amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: My lady keeps a court then, is sir Thomas
Affected with this state and cost.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: He was not,
But is converted, and I hope you won't
Persist in heresy, but take a course
Of riot to content your friends, you shall
Want nothing, if you can be proud and spend it
For my lady's honour, here are a hundred
Pieces, will serve you till you have new clothes,
I will present you with a nag of mine
Poor tender of my service, please you accept,
My lady's smile more than rewards me for it,
I must provide fit servants to attend you,
Monsieurs for horse and foot.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I shall submit
If this be my aunt's pleasure and be ruled
My eyes are opened with this purse already,
And sack will help to inspire me, I must spend it,

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: What else sir?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I'll begin with you, to encourage
You, to have still a special care of me,
There is five pieces, not for your nag.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: No sir, I hope it is not.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Buy a beaver
For thy own block, I shall be ruled, who does
Command the wine-cellar?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Who command but you sir?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I'll try to drink a health or two, my ants
Or anybody's , and if that foundation
Stagger me not too much, I will commence
In all the arts of London.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: If you find sir
The operation of the wine, exalt
Your blood to the desire of any female
Delight, I know your aunt wonot deny
Any of her chambermaids to practise on,
She loves you but too well.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I know not how
I may be for that exercise, farewell Aristotle,
Prithee commend me to the library
At Westminster, my bones I bequeath thither,
And to the learned worms that mean to visit 'em,
I will compose myself, I begin to think
I have lost time indeed, come to the wine-cellar. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But shall we not madam expose ourselves
To censure for this freedom.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Let them answer
That dare mistake us, shall we be so much
Cowards to be frighted from our pleasure,
Because men have malicious tongues, and show
What miserable souls they have, no cozen,
We hold our life and fortunes, upon no
Man's charity, if they dare show so little
Discretion to traduce our fames, we will
Be guilty of so much wit to laugh at 'em.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: 'Tis a becoming fortitude.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My stars
Are yet kind to me, for in a happy minute
Be't spoke, I'm not in love, and men shall never.
Make my heart lean with sighing, nor with tears
Draw on my eyes the infamy of spectacles,
'Tis the chief principle to keep your heart
under your own obedience, jest, but love not,
I say my prayers yet, can wear good clothes,
And only satisfy my tailor for 'em.
I wonot lose my privilege.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And yet they say your entertainments are,
Give me your pardon madam ▪ to proclaim
Yourself a widow, and to get a husband.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: As if a lady of my years, some beauty
Left by her husband rich, that had mourned for him
A twelvemonth too, could live so obscure i'th town
That gallants would not know her, and invite
Themselves without her chargeable proclamations,
Than we are worse than citizens, no widow
Left wealthy can be thoroughly warm in mourning,
But some one noble blood or lusty kindred
Claps in, with his gilt coach, and Flandrian trotters,
And hurries 〈◊〉 away to be a countess.
Courtier's have ●●ies, and great ones with large titles,
Cold in their own estates, would warm themselves
At a rich city bonfire.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: Most true madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No matter for corruption of the blood,
Some undone courtier made her husband rich,
And this new lord receives it back again.
Admit it were my policy, and that
My entertainments pointed to acquaint me
With many suitors, that I might be safe,
And make the best election, could you blame me?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Madam 'tis wisdom.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But I should be
In my thoughts miserable to be fond
Of leaving the sweet freedom I possess,
And court myself into new marriage fetters,
I now observe men's several wits, and windings,
And can laugh at their follies.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: You have given
A most ingenious satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: One thing I'll tell you more, and this I give you
Worthy your imitation from my practice,
You see me merry, full of song and dancing,
pleasant in language, apt to all delights
That crown a public meeting, but you cannot
Accuse me of being prodigal of my favours
To any of my guests, I do not summon
By any wink, a gentleman to follow me,
To my withdrawing chamber, I hear all
Their pleas in court, nor can they boast abroad
And do me justice, after a salute
They have much conversation with my lip,
I hold the kissing of my hand a courtesy,
And he that loves me, must upon the strength
Of that, expect till I renew his favour.
Some ladies are so expensive in their graces,
To those that honour 'em, and so prodigal
That in a little time, they have nothing but
The naked sin left to reward their servants,
Whereas a thrift in our rewards, will keep
Men long in their devotion, and preserve
Ourselves in stock, to encourage those that honour us.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: This is an art worthy a lady's practise.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It takes not from the freedom of our mirth,
But seems to advance it, when we can possess
Our pleasures with security of our honour,
And that preserved, I welcome all the joys
My fancy can let in. In this I have given
The copy of my mind, nor do I blush,
You understand it. Enter Celestina's gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: You have honoured us.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.l: Madam, sir William sentlove's come to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There's one would be a client, make excuse
For a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: One that comes a-wooing ?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Such a thing he would seem, but in his guiltiness
Of little land, his expectation is not
So valiant as it might be, he wears clothes,
And feeds with noblemen, to some I hear
No better than a wanton emissary,
Or scout for Venus' wild foul, which made tame,
He thinks no shame to stand court centinel,
in hope of the reversion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have heard
That some of them are often my lords tasters,
The first fruits they condition for, and will
Exact as fees for the promotion.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Let them agree, there's no account shall lie
For me among their traffic.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.l: Mr. Hairecut madam
Is new come in, to tender you his service.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Let him discourse a little with sir William. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What is this gentleman Mr. Hairecut madam?
I note him very gallant, and much courted
By gentlemen of quality.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know not
More than a trim gay man, he has some great office
Sure by his confident behaviour,
He would be entertained under the title
Of servant to me, and I must confess,
He is the sweetest of all men that visit me.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: How mean you madam?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: He is full of powder,
He will save much in perfume for my chamber,
Were he but constant here; give 'em access.

div.stage: Enter sir Will. Sentlove, Mr. Hairecut.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Madam the humblest of your servants is
Exalted to a happiness, if you smile
Upon my visit.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I must beg your charity
Upon my rudeness madam, I shall give
That day up lost to any happiness,
When I forget to tender you my service.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You practise courtship gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: But cannot
Find where with more desert to exercise it,
What lady's this I pray?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: A kinswoman
Of mine sir William.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I am more her servant,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You came from court, now I presume.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Tis madam
The sphere I move in, and my destiny
Was kind to place me there, where i enjoy
All blessings that a mortal can possess,
that lives not in your presence, and i should
Fix my ambition, when you would vouchsafe
Me so much honour, to accept from me
An humble entertainment there.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But by
What name shall I be known, in what degree
Shall i be of kindred to you.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.l: How mean you madam?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Perhaps you'll call me sister, I shall take it
A special preferment, or it may be
I may pass under title of your mistress,
If I seem rich, and fair enough, to engage
Your confidence to own me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I would hope.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But 'tis not come to that yet, you will sir
Excuse my mirth.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Shall i take
Boldness to ask what place you hold in court?
'Tis an uncivil curiosity,
But you'll have mercy to a woman's question.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My present condition madam, carries
Honour and profit, though not to be named
With that employment i expect ith' state
Which shall discharge the first maturity
Upon your knowledge, until than I beg
You allow a modest silence.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am charmed sir,
And if you scape ambassador, you cannot
Reach a preferment, wherein I'm against you,
But where's sir William Sentlove?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Give him leave
To follow his nose madam, while he hunts
In view, he'll soon be at a fault.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You know him.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Know Sentlove? not a page but can decipher him,
The waiting women know him to a scruple,
He's called the blistermaker of the town.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: The laundry ladies can resolve you,
And you may guess, an arrant epicure
As this day lives, born to a pretty wit,
A knight but no gentleman, i must
Be plain to you, your ladyship may have
use of this knowledge, but conceal the author.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: I kiss your fairest hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You make a difference,
Pray reconcile 'em to an equal whiteness.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: You wound my meaning lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nay sir William
Has the art of compliment.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Madam, you honour me
Above my desert of language.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Will you please
To enrich me with your knowledge of that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Do you not know him madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: A camphire ball, you shall know more hereafter
He shall tell you himself, and save my character,
Till then, you see he's proud.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: One thing gentlemen
I observe in your behaviour, which is rare
In two that court one mistress, you preserve
A noble friendship, there's no gum within
Your hearts, you cannot fret, or show an envy
Of one another's hope, some would not govern
Their passions with that temper.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: The whole world
Sha'not divorce our friendship. Mr. Hairecut
Would I had lives to serve him, he is lost
To goodness does not honour him.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My knight I

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: This is right playing at court shuttlecock.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.l: Madam, there is a gentleman desires
To speak w'ee, one sir Thomas Bornwell.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Bornewell?

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.l: He says he is a stranger to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: I know him.

sp.speaker: Hair ▪
sp.l: Your neighbour madam.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Husband to the lady, that so revels in the strand.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: He has good parts they say, but cannot help
His lady's bias.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: They have both much fame
Ith' town for several merits, pray admit him.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What comes he for? Enter sir Thomas ▪

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your pardon noble lady, that I have
Presumed a stranger to your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir,
Your worth was here before you, and your person
Cannot be here ingrateful.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: 'Tis the bounty
Of your sweet disposition madam, make me
your servant lady by her fair example,
To favour me — I never knew one turn
Her cheek to a gentleman that came to kiss her
But she'd a stinking breath; your servant gentlemen,
Will sent love how is't?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am sorry coz
To accuse you, we in nothing more betray
Ourselves to censure of ridiculous pride,
Then answering a fair salute too rudely,
O it shows ill upon a gentlewoman
Not to return the modest lip, if she
Would have the world believe, her breath is not
Offensive.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Madam, I have business
With you.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: His looks are pleasant.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I hear you have an excellent wit madam,
I see your fair

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: The first is but report,
And do not trust your eyesight for the last,
'Cause I presume you're mortal and may err.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: He is very gamesome.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You've an excellent voice;
They say you catch it from a dying swan,
Which joined to the sweet harmony of your lute,
You ravish all mankind.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Ravish mankind?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: With their consent.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It were the stranger rape,
But there's the less indictment lies against it,
And there is hope; your little honesties
Cannot be much the worse, for men do rather
Believe they had a maiden head, then put
Themselves to'th rack of memory, how long
'Tis since they left the burden of their innocence.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Why you are bitter madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: So is physic,
I do not know your constitution.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You shall if please you madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You're too hasty,
I must examine what certificate
You have, first to prefer you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Fine! certificate?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Under your lady's hand, and seal.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Go to,
I see you are a wag.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But take heed, how
You trust to't.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I can love you in my wedlock,
As well as that young gallant, oath first hair,
Or the knight bachelor, and can return
as amorous delight to thy soft bosom.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Your person and your language are both strangers.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But may be more familiar, I have those
That dare make affidavit for my body.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: D'ye mean your surgeon?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: My surgeon madam ▪
I know not how you value my abilities,
But I dare undertake, as much, to express
My service to your ladyship, and with
As fierce ambition, fly to your commands,
As the most valiant of these, 'Lay siege to you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You dare not sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How madam?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I will instifi't.
You dare not marry me, and I imagine
Some here should I consent, would fetch a priest
Out of the fire.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I have a wife indeed,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And there's a statute not repealed I take it.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You're in the right I must confess you've hit,
And bled me in a master vein.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You think
I took you on the advantage, use your best
Skill at defence, I'll come up to your valour
And show another work you dare not do,
You dare not sir be virtuous.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I dare,
By this fair hand, I dare, and ask a pardon
If my rude words offend thy innocence,
Which in a form so beautiful, would shine
To force a blush in them suspected it,
And from the rest draw wonder.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I like not
Their secret parley, shall I interrupt 'em?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: By no means sir.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Sir Thomas was not wont
To show so much a courtier.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He cannot
Be prejudicial to you, suspect not
Your own deserts so much, he's married.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I have other business madam, you keep music,
I came to try how you can dance.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You did? I'll try his humour out of breath ▪
Although boast no cunning sir in revels,
If you desire to show your art that way,
I can wait on you.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You much honour me,
Nay all must join to make a harmony.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I have nothing now, madam, but to beseech
After a pardon for my boldness, you
Would give occasion to pay my gratitude,
I have a house will be much honoured
If you vouchsafe your presence, and a wife
Desires to present herself your servant,
I came with the ambition to invite you,
Deny me not, your person you shall trust
On fair security.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir, although I use not
This freedom with a stranger, you shall have
No cause to hold me obstinate.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You grace me
Sir William Sentlove —

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I must take my leave,
You will excuse me madam, court attendances —

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: By any means.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ladies you will vouchsafe
Your company.

sp.speaker: Is. m.
sp.l: We wait upon you sir. Exunt.

div.head: The third act.
div.stage: Enter lord unready. Hairecut preparing his periwig, table, and looking-glass.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What hour is't?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Bout three o'clock my lord.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: 'Tis time to rise.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Your lordship went but late
To bed last night.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: 'Twas early in the morning. Enter secre.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Expect a while, my lord is busy?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Here is a lady
Desires access to you upon some affairs
She says may specially concern your lordship.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A lady? What her name?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Madam Decoy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Decoy? prithee admit her. Enter Decoy.
Have you business madam
With me?

sp.speaker: Decoy.
sp.l: And such I hope as will not be
Offensive to your lordship.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I pray speak it.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I would desire your lordship's ear more private.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Wait i'th next chamber till I call, now madam. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Although I am a stranger to your lordship
I would not lose a fair occasion offered.
To show how much I honour, and would serve you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Please you to give me the particular
that I may know the extent of my engagement,
I am ignorant by what desert you should
Be encouraged to have care of me.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: My lord,
I will take boldness to be plain, beside
Your other excellent parts, you have much fame
For your sweet inclination to our sex.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How d'ye mean madam?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I that way your lordship
Hath honourably practised upon some
Not to be named, your noble constancy
To a mistress hath deserved our general vote,
And I a part of woman kind have thought
How to express my duty.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: In what madam?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Be not so strange my lord, I know the beauty
And pleasures of your eyes, that handsome creature
With whose fair life all your delight took leave,
And to whose memory you have paid too much ▪
Sad tribute.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What's all this?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: This, if your lordship
Accept my service, in pure zeal to cure
Your melancholy, I could point where you might
Repair your loss.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your ladyship I conceive
Doth traffic in flesh merchandise.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: To men.
Of honour like yourself, I am well known
To some in court and come not with ambition
Now to supplant your officer.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What is
The lady of pleasure you prefer.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: A lady
Of birth and fortune, one upon whose virtue
I may presume, the lady Aretina ▪

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Wife to sir Thomas Bornwell?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: The same sir ▪

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Have you prepared her?
Not for your lordship, till I have found your pulse,
I am acquainted with her disposition
She has a very appliable nature.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And madam when expect you to be whipped
For doing these fine favours.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: How my lord?
Your lordship does but jest I hope; you make
A difference between a lady that
Does honourable offices, and one
They call a bawd, your lordship was not wont
to have such course opinion of our practice.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: The lady Aretina is my kinswoman.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: What if she be my lord? the nearer blood
The dearer sympathy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I'll have thee carted.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Your lordship wonot so much stain your honour
And education, to use a woman
Of my quality. — lord. — 'tis possible you may
Be sent off with an honourable convoy
Of halberdiers.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: O my good lord!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your ladyship shall be no protection
If thou but stayest three minutes.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I am gone,
When next you find rebellion in your blood,
May all within ten mile o'th court turn honest. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I do not find that proneness since the fair
Bella Maria died, my blood is cold,
Nor is there beauty enough surviving
To heighten me to wantonness, who waits?
And what said my lady? Enter Hairecut.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The silent language of her face my lord
Was not so pleasant, as it showed upon
Her entrance.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Would any man that meets
This lady take her for a bawd.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: She does
The trade an honour, credit to the profession,
We may in time see baldness, quarter noses,
And rotten legs to take the wall of foot-cloths.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I ha' thought better, call the lady back,
I wonot lose this opportunity,
Bid her not fear, the favour is not common,
And I'll reward it. I do wonder much
Will Sentlove was not here today.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I heard him say this morning, he would wait
Upon your lordship.
She is returned sir. Enter secre. and Decoy.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Madam be confident my lords not angry.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You return welcome madam, you are better
Read in your art I hope then to be frighted
With any shape of anger, when you bring
Such news to gentlemen, madam you shall
soon understand how I accept the office.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: You are the first lord, since i studied carriage,
That showed such infidelity and fury
Upon so kind a message, every gentleman
Will show some breeding, but if one right honourable
Should not have noble blood.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You shall return
My compliment in a letter to my lady
Aretina, favour me with a little patience,
Show her that chamber.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I'll attend your lordship. Ex.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Write. Madam where your honour is in danger,
My love must not be silent. Enter Sentlove and Kickshaw.
Sentlove and Kickshaw!

sp.speaker: Kickshaw
sp.l: Your lordship's busy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Writing a letter, nay it sha'not bar
Any discourse.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: — Silent.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Though I be no physician, I may prevent a fever in your blood.
And where have you spent the morning's conversation?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Where you would have given the best Barbary
In your stable to have met on honourable terms.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What new beauty? You acquaint yourselves
With none but wonders.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: 'Tis too low a miracle ▪

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: 'Twill require a strong faith.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Your blood.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: If you be innocent preserve your fame lest this Decoy
Madam betray it to your repentance.
By what name is she known?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Ask Alexander, he knows her?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: The lady Celestina.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: He has a vast knowledge of ladies, 'las poor Alexander!
When dost thou mean thy body shall lie fallow?

sp.speaker: Al
sp.l: When there is mercy in a petticoat,
I must turn pilgrim for some breath.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I think
'Twere cooler travel if you examine it
Upon the hoof through Spain.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Through Ethiopia ▪

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay less laborious to serve a prenticeship
In Peru, and dig gold out of the mine,
Though all the year were dog-days.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: To repentance,

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: In brief, this lady, could you fall from virtue,
Within my knowledge will not blush to be a bawd.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: But hang't 'tis honourable journey work,
Thou art famous by't, and thy name's up.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: So sir ▪
Let me ask you a question my dear knight,
Which is less servile to bring up the pheasant,
And wait, or sit at table uncontrolled
And carve to my own appetite?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: No more,
Thou'rt witty, as I am —

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: A bawd.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O you are famous by't, and your names up sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Be wise, and reward my caution, with
Timely care of yourself, so I shall not repent
To be known your lovings kinsman and servant.
Gentlemen, the lady Celestina.
Is she so rare a thing?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: If you'll have my
Opinion my lord, I never saw
So sweet, so fair, so rich a piece of nature.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I'll show thee a fairer presently, to shame
Thy eyes and judgement, look o'that. — so I'll subscribe
Seal it, I'll excuse your pen for the direction.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Bella Maria's picture; she was handsome.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: But not to be compared.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your patience gentlemen I'll return instantly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Whither is my lord gone?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: To a lady i'th next chamber.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: What is she?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: You shall pardon me, I am his secretary.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: I was wont to be of his counsel, a new officer
And i not know't? I am resolved to 'Batter
All other with the praise of Celestina
I must retain him. Enter lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Has not that object
Convinced your erring judgements.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What this picture?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Were but your thoughts as capable as mine
Of her idea, you would wish no thought
That were not active in her praise, above
All worth and memory of her sex.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: She was fair
I must confess, but had your lordship looked
With eyes more narrow and some less affection
Upon her face.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I do not love the copies
of any dead, they make me dream of goblins,
Give me a living mistress, with but half
The beauty of Celestina, come my lord,
'Tis pity that a lord of so much flesh
Should waste upon a ghost, when they are living
Can give you a more honourable consumption.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Why do you mean my lord to live an infidel?
Do, and see what will come on't, observe still
And dote upon your vigils, build a chamber
Within a rock, a tomb, among the worms,
Not far off, where you may in proof apocryphal
Court 'em not devour the pretty pile.
Of flesh your mistress carried to the grave,
There are no women in the world, all eyes
And tongue and lips are buried in her coffin.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why do you think yourselves competent judges.
Of beauty gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: What should hinder us?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I have seen and tried as many as another
With a mortal back.

sp.speaker: Lord ▪
sp.l: Your eyes are bribed,
And your hearts chained to some desires, you cannot
Enjoy the freedom of a sense.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Your lordship
Has a clear eyesight, and can judge and penetrate.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I can, and give a perfect censure of
Each line and point, distinguish beauty from
A thousand forms, which your corrupted optiks
Would pass for natural.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I desire no other
Judge should determine us, and if your lordship
Dare venture but your eyes upon this lady,
I'll stand their justice, and be confident
You shall give Celestine victory,
And triumph o'er all beauties past and living.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I dare my lord venture a suit of clothes,
You will be o'ercome.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You do not know my fortitude

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Nor frailty, you dare not trust you self to see her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Think you so gentlemen, I dare see this creature
To make you know your errors ▪ and the difference
Of her, whose memory is my saint, not trust
My senses? I dare see and speak with her,
which holds the best acquaintance to prepare
My visit to her.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I will do't my lord.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: She is a lady free in entertainments.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I would give this advantage to your cause,
Bid him appear in all the ornaments
Did ever wait on beauty, all the riches
Pride can put on, and teach her face more charm
Than ever poet dressed up Venus in,
Bid her be all the graces, and the Queen
Of love in one, I'll see her Sentlove, and
Bring off my heart armed, but single thought
Of one that is dead, without a wound, and when
I have made your folly prisoner, I'll laugh at you.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: She shall expect you, trust to me for knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I'm for the present somewhere else engaged,
Let me hear from you.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: So I am glad he's yet
So near conversion.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I am for Aretina.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: No mention of my lord.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Prepare his lady,
'Tis time he were reduced to the old sport,
One lord like him more would undo the court. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Aretina with a letter. Decoy.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: He is the ornament of your blood madam,
I am much bound to his lordship.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: He gives you
A noble character.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: 'Tis his goodness madam.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I wanted such an engine, my lord has
Done me a courtesy to disclose her nature,
I now know one to trust, and will employ her.
Touching my lord, for reasons, which I shall
Offer to your ladyship hereafter, I
Desire you would be silent, but to show
How much I dare be confident in your secrecy,
I pour my bosom forth, I love a gentleman
On whom there won't meet much conjuration
To meet — your ear ▪ —

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I apprehend you, and I shall
Be happy to be serviceable, I am sorry
Your ladyship did not know me before now,
I have done offices, and not a few
Of the nobility, but have done feats
Within my house, which is so convenient
For situation, and artful chambers,
Such pretty pictures to provoke the fancy.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Madam all pleasures languish in your absence.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Your pardon a few minute's sir — you must
Contrive it thus.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: I attend, and shall account it
Honour to wait on your return.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: He may not
Have the least knowledge of my name, or person.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I have practised that already for some great ones,
And dare again to satisfy you madam;
I have a thousand ways to do sweet offices.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: If this lady Aretina should be honest,
I ha' lost time, she's free as air, i must
Have closer conference, and if I have art,
Make her affect me in revenge.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: This evening
Leave me to manage things.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You will oblige me.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: You shall commend my art, and thank me after. Ex.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I hope the revels are maintained within.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: By sir Thomas and his mistress.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: How? his mistress.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: The lady Celestina, I ne'er saw
Eyes shoot more amorous interchange.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Is't so?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: He wears her favour with mere pride.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Her favour.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: A feather that he ravished from her fan.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: And is so full of courtship, which she smiles on.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: And praises her beyond all poetry.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I'm glad he has so much wit.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Not jealous!

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: This secures me, what would make other ladies pale
With jealousy, gives but a licence to my wanderings,
Let him now tax me if he dare — and yet
Her beauty's worth my envy, and I wish
Revenge upon it, not because he loves,
But that it shines above my own. Enter Alex.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Dear madam.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I have it, you two gentlemen profess
Much service to me, if I have a way
to employ your wit and secrecy.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: You'll honour us.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You gave a high and worthy character
Of Celestina.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I remember madam.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Do either of you love her.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Nor I madam.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: I would not if I might.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: She's now my guest,
And by a trick invited by my husband
To disgrace me, you gentlemen are held
Wits of the town, the consuls that do govern
The senate here, whose jeers are all authentic,
The taverns and the ordinaries are
Made academies where you come, and all
Your sins and surfeits made times example,
Your very nods can quell a theater,
No speech or poem good without your seal,
You can protect scurrility, and publish
By your authority believed, no rapture
Ought to have honest meaning.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Leave our characters.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: And name the employment.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You must exercise
The strength of both your wits upon this lady,
And talk her into humbleness or anger
Both which are equal to my thought, if you
Dare undertake this slight thing for my sake,
My favour shall reward it, but be faithful,
And seem to let all spring from your own freedom.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: This all? We can defame her, if you please
My friend shall call her whore or any thing,
And never be endangered to a duel.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: He can endure a cudgelling, and no man
Will fight after so fair a satisfaction,
But leave us to our art, and do not limit us.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: They are here, begin not till I whisper you.

div.stage: Enter sir Thomas, Celestina, Marcana, Isabella.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Je vous prie madam d' excuser l'importunitè de mes affairs
Qui m' on't fait offenser, par mon, absence, une dame de laquelle
I'ay receu tant d' obligation.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pardonnez moy madame; vous me faictez trop a honneur.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: C'est bien de la douceur de vostre naturel que vous tenez
Ceste language; mais j'espere que mon marry na pas
manquè de vous entretenir en mon absence.

sp.speaker: Ce.
sp.l: En verity monsieur nous a fort obligè

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.p: Il eut trop failly, s'il n'eust taschè de tout fon pouvoir à vous rendre toutes sorts de services.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Cest de sa bonté qu'il nous a tant favorisé.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: De la vostre plustost madame que vous fait donner
D'interpretation si benign à says efforts.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Je voy bien que la victoire fera toutsjours à madame, and de language, and de la courtesy.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Vrayement madame, que jamais personne a plus desire,
L'honneur de vostre company, que moy.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Laissons en●je vous supplis, des compliments and permiettoz à vostre servant de vous baiser les mains.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Vous m'obligez trop.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I have no more patience, let's be merry again
In our own language, madam our mirth cools,
Our nephew! Enter Frederick.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Passion of my brain.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Save you gentlemen, save you ladies.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I must salute, no matter at which end I begin.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: There's a compliment.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is this your nephew madam?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Je vous prie madame d'execuser les habitz, and le rude
Comportement de mon cousin. Il est tout fraischement
Venu de l university, ou on l'a tout gastè.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: Excusez moy madam, il est bien accomply.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: This language should be French, by the motions
Of your heads, and the mirth of your faces.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I am dishonoured.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: 'Tis one of the finest tongues for ladies to show their
Teeth in, if you'll Latin I am for you, or Greek it,
My tailor has not put me into French yet,
Mille basia, basia mille.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Je ne vous intend pas monsieur,
I understand you not sir.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why so?
You and I then shall be in charity,
For though we should be abusive, we ha' the benefit
Not to understand one another: where's my aunt?
I did hear music somewhere, and my brains
tuned with a bottle of your capering claret
Made haste to show their dancing.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Please you madam,
They are very comfortable.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Alas madam
How would you have me help it, I did use
All means I could, after he heard the music,
To make him drunk in hope so to contain him,
But the wine made him lighter, and his head
Flew hither, ere I missed his heels.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: Nay he spoke Latin to the lady.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: O most unpardonable! get him off
Quickly, and discreetly, or if I live —

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: 'Tis not in my power he swears I am
An absurd sober fellow, and if you keep
A servant in his house to cross his humour,
When the rich sword and belt comes home, he'll kill him.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What shall I do? Try your skill, master Littleworth.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: He has never a sword, sweet Mr. Frederick ▪

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: 'Tis pity madam such a syen should
Be lost, but you are clouded.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not I sir,
I never found myself more clear at heart.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I could play with a feather, your fan lady,
Gentlemen, Aretina, ta ra ra ra, come madam.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why my good tutor in election?
You might have been a scholar.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: But I thank
My friends they brought me up a little better,
Give me the town wits, that deliver jests
Clean from the bow, that whistle in the air,
And cleave the pin at twelvescore, ladies do
But laugh at a gentleman that has any learning.
'Tis sin enough to have your clothes suspected,
Leave us, and I will find a time to instruct you;
Come here are sugar plumbs, 'tis a good Frederick.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why is not this my aunt's house in the strand?
The noble rendezvous? Who laughs at me?
Go, I will root here ▪ if I list, and talk
Of rhetoric, logic, Latin, Greek, or any thing,
And understand 'em too, who says the contrary?
Yet in a fair way I contemn all learning,
and will be ignorant as he, or he,
Or any taffeta, satin, scarlet, plush,
Tissue, or cloth, a bodkin gentleman,
Whose manners are most gloriously infected;
Did you laugh at me lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not I sir?
But if I did show mirth upon your question,
I hope you would not beat me little gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: How little gentleman? you dare not say
These words to my new clothes, and fighting sword.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Nephew Frederick!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Little gentleman,
This an affront both to my blood and person,
I am a gentleman of as tall a birth
As any least nobility, though my clothes
Smell o'the lamp, my coat is honourable,
Right honourable, full, of or, and argent,
A little gentleman!

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Coz you must be patient,
My lady meant you no dishonour, and
You must remember she's a woman.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Is she a woman, that's another matter,
D'ye hear, my uncle tells me what you are.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You called me little gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I did sir.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: A little pink has made a lusty ship
Strike her topsail, the crow may beard the elephant,
A whelp may tame the tiger, spite of all
False decks and murderers, and a little gentleman
Be hard enough to grapple with your ladyship
Top and top gallant; will you go drink uncle?
Tother enchanted bottle, you and I
Will tipple, and talk philosophy.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Come nephew,
You will excuse a minute's absence madam.
Wait you on us.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: My duty sir.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Now gentlemen. Ex. all but Cel. and Alex. and little.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Madam I had rather you accuse my language
For speaking truth, than virtue suffer in
My further silence, and it is my wonder
That you, whose noble carriage hath deserved
All honour, and opinion should now
be guilty of ill manners.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What was that
You told me sir?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Do you not blush madam?
To ask that question.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You amaze rather
My cheek to paleness, what you mean by this?
I am not troubled with the hickup gentlemen,
You should bestow this fright upon me.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Then
Pride and ill memory go together.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: The gentleman on whom you exercise
Your thin wit, was a nephew to the lady
Whose guest you are, and though her modesty
Look calm on the abuse of one so near
Her blood, the affront was impious.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: I am ashamed on't,
You an ingenious lady and well mannered?
I'll reach a bear as much civility.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You may be master of the college sir
For ought I know.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: What college? Of the bears.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Have you a plot upon me? D'ye possess
Your wits, or know me gentlemen. Enter Bornewell.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Know you? yes we do know you to an atom.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Madam we know, what stuff your soul is made on.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But do not bark so like a mastive, pray,
Sure they are mad, let your brains stand awhile
And settle gentlemen, you know not me,
What am I?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Thou'rt a puppet, a thing made
Of clothes and painting, and not half so handsome
As that which played Susanna in the fair.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I heard you visited those canvas tragedies,
One of their constant audience, and so taken
With Susan, that you wished yourself a rival
With the two wicked elders.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You think this
Is wit now, come you are —

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What I beseech you?
Your character will be full of salt and satire,
No doubt, what am I?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why you are a woman.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And that's at least a bow wide of you knowledge.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Would be thought handsome, and might pass i'th country
Upon a market day, but miserably
Forfeit to pride and fashions, that if heaven
were a new gown, you'd not stay in't a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It must be miserably out of fashion then,
Have I no sin but pride?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Hast any virtue?
Or but a good face to excuse that want?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You praised it yesterday.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That made you proud.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: More pride?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You need not to close up the praise,
I have seen a better countenance in a sibyl.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: When you wore spectacles of sack, mistook
The painted cloth, and kissed it for your mistress.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Let me ask you a question, how much
Have you consumed in expectation
That I would love you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Why? I think as much
As you have paid a way in honest debts
This seven year, 'tis a pretty impudence,
But cannot make me angry.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Is there any
Man that will cast away his limbs upon her?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You do not sing so well as I imagined,
Nor dance, you reel in your coranto, and pinch
Your petticoat too hard, you've no good ear
Toth' music, and incline too much one shoulder,
As you were dancing on the rope, and falling,
You speak abominable French, and make
A curtsy like a dairy maid, not mad?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Do we not sting her handsomely

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: A conspiracy.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Your state is not so much as 'tis reported
When you confer notes, all your husband's debts
And your own reconciled — but that's not it
Will so much spoil your marriage.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: As what sir?
Let me know all my faults.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Some men do whisper
You are not over honest.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: All this shall not
Move me to more than laughter, and some pity,
Because you have the shapes of gentlemen,
And though you have been insolent upon me,
I will engage no friend to kick or cudgel you
To spoil your living, and your limbs together,
I leave that to diseases that offend you,
And spare my curse, poor silken vermin, and
Hereafter shall distinguish men from monkeys.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Brave soul, you brace of horseleeches, I have heard
Their barbarous language madam, you're too merciful,
They shall be silent to your tongue, pray punish 'em.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: They are things not worth my character, nor mention
Of any clean breath, so lost in honesty
They cannot satisfy for wrongs enough,
Though they should steal out of the world at Tyburn.
