sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: We are hanged already.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yet I will talk a little to the pilchards,
You two that have not twixt you both the hundred
Part of a soul, course woollen witted fellows,
Without a nap, with bodies made for burdens,
You that are only stuffings for apparel
As you were made but engines for your tailors
To frame their clothes upon, and get them custom;
Until men see you move, yet, than you dare not
Out of your guilt of being the ignobler beast
But give a horse the wall, whom you excel
Only in dancing of the brawls, because
The horse was not taught the French way, your two faces,
One fat like Christmas, tother lean like Candlemas,
And prologue to a lent, both bound together
Would figure Janus, and do many cures
On agues and the green disease by frighting,
But neither can with all the characters
And conjuring circles charm a woman, though
She'd fourscore years upon her, and but one
Tooth in her head, to love or think well of you;
And I were miserable, to be at cost
To court such a complexion, as your malice
Did impudently insinuate, but I waste time
And stain my breath in talking to such tadpoles.
Go home and wash your tongues in barley water
Drink clean tobacco, be not hot i'th mouth,
And you may scape the beadle; so I leave you
To shame and your own garters, sir I must
Entreat you for my honour do not penance 'em ▪
They are not worth your anger, how I shall
Acquit your lady's silence.
Madam, I
Am sorry to suspect, and dare revenge

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No ▪ cause 〈◊〉 mine.

sp.speaker: B●r.
sp.l: It must become me to attend you home.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You are noble — — farewell mushrooms.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Is she gone.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: I think we peppered her ▪

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am glad 'tis over ▪
But I repent no service for you madam.
To me? from whence a jewel a good preface,
Be happy the conclusion.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Some love letter —He smiles upon.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: He has a hundred mistresses, you may
Be charitable madam I ha' none,
He surfeits, and I fall away ●th kidneys.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I'll meet,
'Tis some great lady questionless, that has
Taken notice, and would satisfy her appetite.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Now Mr. Alexander, you look bright o'the sudden,
Another spirit's in your eye.

sp.speaker: Al ▪
sp.l: Not 〈◊〉 madam ▪
Only a 〈◊〉 to 〈◊〉 a friend.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What friend?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: By this jewel, I know her not ▪

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis a she friend ▪ I'll follow gentlemen,
We may have a game 〈◊〉 before you go ▪

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I shall attend you 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: 'Tis our duty.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I blush 〈…〉 my own thoughts,
Some strange face governs me, 〈…〉
The ways are East already and we thrive
When our sin fears no eye nor perspective. Exit.

div.head: The fourth act ▪
div.stage: Enter two men leading Alexander ●●ded, and go of suddenly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am not hurt, my patience to obey ▪ 'em
Not without fear to ha' my throat cut else,
Did me a courtesy 〈◊〉 ha' they brought me
'Tis devilish dark, the bottom of a well
At midnight, with but two stars on the top,
Were broad day to this darkness, I but think
How like a whirlwind these rogues caught me up
and smothered my eyesight, let me see,
These may be spirits, and for ought I know
Have brought me hither over twenty steeples,
Pray heaven they were not bailiffs; that's more worth
My fear, and this a prison, all my debts
Reek in my nostril, and my bones begin
To ache with fear to be made dice, and yet
This is too calm and quiet for a prison;
What if the riddle prove I am robbed; and yet
I did not feel 'em search me? How now? music?
sp.stage: Enter Decoy like an old woman with a light.
sp.l: And a light? What beldame's this, I cannot pray;
What art?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: A friend, fear not young man I am
No spirit.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Off. de. Despise me not for age,
Or this course outside, which I wear not out
Of poverty; thy eyes be witness, 'tis
No cave or beggar's cell thou'rt brought too, let
That gold speak here's no want, which thou mayst spend,
And find a spring to tire even prodigality
If thou beest wise ▪

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The devil was a coiner
From the beginning, yet the gold looks currant.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Thou'rt still in wonder, know I am mistress of
This house, and of a fortune that shall serve
And feed thee with delights, 'twas i sent for thee,
The jewel and the letter came from me ▪
It was my art, thus to contrive our meeting,
Because i would not trust thee with my fame,
Until i found thee worth a woman's honour.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Honour and fame? the devil means to have
A care on's credit, though she sent for me,
I hope, she has another customer
To do the trick withal, i would not turn
Familiar to a witch.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: What sayest? Canst thou
Dwell in my arms tonight , shall we change kisses,
And entertain the silent hours with pleasure?
Such as old time shall be delighted with,
And blame the too swift motion of his wings
While we embrace.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Embrace? she has had no teeth
This twenty years, and the next violent cough
brings up her tongue, it cannot possibly
Be sound at root, I do not think but one
Strong sneeze upon her, and well meant would make
Her quarters fall away, one kick would blow
Her up like gunpowder, and lose all her limbs;
She is so cold, an incubus would not heat her,
Her phlegm would quench a furnace, and her breath
Would damp a musket bullet.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Have you sir
Considered.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: My proposition,
Canst love?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I could have done, whom do you mean?
I know you are pleased, but to make sport.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Thou art not
So dull of soul as thou appearest.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: This is.
But some device, my granam has some trick in't:
Yes I can love.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: But canst thou affect me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Although to reverence so grave a matron
Were an ambitious word in me, yet since
You give me boldness, I do love you.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Then
Thou art my own.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Has she no cloven foot?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: And I am thine, and all that I command
Thy servants, from this minute thou are happy,
And fate in thee will crown all my desires.
I grieved a proper man should be compelled
To bring his body to the common market,
My wealth shall make thee glorious, and the more
To encourage thee, howe'er this form may fright
Thy youthful eyes, yet thou wilt find by light
Of thy own sense, for other light is banished
My chamber, when our arms tie lovers knots,
And kisses seal the welcome of our lips,
I shall not there affright thee, nor seem old,
With riveled veins, my skin is smooth and soft
As ermines, with a spirit to meet thine,
Active and equal to the Queen of love's
When she did court Adonis.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This doth more
Confirm she is a devil, and I am
Within his own dominions, I must on,
Or else be torn a pieces, I have heard
These succubi must not be crossed.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: We trifle
Too precious time away, I'll show you a prospect
of the next chamber, and then out the candle.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Have you no sack i'th house, I would go armed
Upon this breach.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: It sha'not need.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: One word
Mother, have not you been a cat in your days?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I am glad you are so merry sir, you observe
That bed.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: A very brave one.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: When you are
Disrobed, you can come thither in the dark,
You sha'not stay for me, come as you wish
For happiness. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am preferred, if I
Be modest and obey, she cannot have
The heart to do me harm, and she were Hecate
Herself, I will have a strong faith, and think,
I march upon a mistress, the less evil,
If I scape fire now, I defy the devil. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: And how d'ye like me now?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Most excellent.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Your opinion Mr. Littlewor.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Your French tailor
Has made you a perfect gentleman, I may
Converse now with you, and preserve my credit,
D'ye find no alteration in your body
With these new clothes?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: My body altered? no.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: You are not yet in fashion then, that must
Have a new motion garb, and posture too,
Or all your pride is cast away, it is not
The cut of your apparel makes a gallant,
But the geometrical wearing of your clothes.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Mr. Littleworth tells you right, you wear your hat:
Too like a citizen.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: 'Tis like a midwife,
Place it with best advantage of your hair,
Is half your feather molted? this does make
No show, it should spread over like a canopy,
Your hot reined monsieur wears it for a shade,
And cooler to his back, your doublet must
Be more unbuttoned hereabouts, you'll not
Be a sloven else, a foul shirt is no blemish,
You must be confident, and outface clean linen!
Your doublet and your breeches must be allowed
No private meeting here, your cloak's too long,
it reaches to your buttock, and doth smell
Too much of Spanish gravity, the fashion
Is to wear nothing but a cape, a coat
May be allowed a covering for one elbow,
And some to avoid the trouble, choose to walk
In cuerpo thus.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Your coat, and cloak's a brushing
In Long-lane Lombard.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But what if it rain?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Your belt about your shoulder is sufficient
To keep off any storm, beside a reed
But waved discreetly, has so many pores,
It sucks up all the rain that falls about one,
With this defence ▪ when other men have been
Wet to the skin through all their cloaks, I have
Defied a tempest and walked by the taverns
Dry as a bone.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Because he had no money
To call for wine.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Why you do walk enchanted,
Have you such pretty charms in town? But stay,
Who must I have to attend me?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Is not that
Yet thought upon.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: I have laid out for servants.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: They are everywhere .

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: I cannot yet be furnished
With such as I would put into his hands.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Of what condition must they be, and how
Many in number sir?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Beside your fencing,
Your singing, dancing, riding, and french-master,
Two may serve domestic to be constant waiters
Upon a gentleman a fool, a pimp.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: For these two officers I have enquired,
And I am promised a convenient whiskin,
I could save charges, and employ the pie wench
That carries her intelligence in whitepots,
Or 'tis but taking order with the woman
That holds the ballads, she could fit him with
A concubine to any tune, but I
Have a design to place a fellow with him
That has read all sir Pandarus works, a Trojan
That lies concealed, and is acquainted with
Both city and suburbian fripperies
Can fetch 'em with a spell at midnight to him,
And warrant which are for his turn, can for
a need supply the surgeon too.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I like
Thy providence, — such a one deserves a livery twice a year ▪

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: It sha'not need, a cast suit of your worships
Will serve, he'll find a cloak to cover it
Out of his share with those he brings to bed to you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But must I call this fellow pimp?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: It is
Not necessary, or Jack, or harry,
Or what he's known abroad by will sound better,
That men may think he is a christian.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But hear you Mr. Littleworth, is there not
A method and degrees of title in
Men of this art.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: According to the honour
Of men that do employ 'em. An emperor
May give this office to a Duke, a King
May have his viceroy to negotiate for him,
A Duke may use a lord, the lord a knight
A knight may trust a gentleman, and when
They are abroad, and merry, gentlemen
May pimp to one another.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Good, good fellowship!
But for the fool now, that should wait on me,
And break me jests.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: A fool is necessary.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: By any means.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But which of these two servants
Must now take place.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: That question Mr. Frederick
The school of heraldry should conclude upon;
But if my judgement may be heard the fool
Is your firstman, and it is known a point
Of state to have a fool.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: But sir the other
Is held the finer servant, his employments
Are full of trust, his person cleave, and nimble,
And none so soon can leap into preferment
Where fools are poor.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Not all, there's story for't,
Princes have been no wiser than they should be,
Would any noble man, that were no fool
Spend all in hope of the philosopher's stone,
To buy new lordships in another country,
Would knights build colleges, or gentlemen
Of good states, challenge the field and fight
Because a whore won't be honest, come,
Fools are a family over all the world;
we do affect one naturally, indeed
The fool is leaguer with us.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Then the pimp
Is extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Do not you fall out
About their places; here's my noble aunt. Aretina.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: How do you like your nephew madam now?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Well, turn about Frederick, very well.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Am I not now a proper gentleman?
The virtue of rich clothes! now could I take
The wall of Julius Cesar, affront
Great Pompey's upperlip, and defy the senate,
Nay I can be as proud as your own heart madam,
You may take that for your comfort; i put on
That virtue with my clothes, and i doubt not
But in little time, i shall be impudent
As any page or player's boy, i am
Beholding to this gentleman's good discipline,
But i shall do him credit in my practice,
Your steward has some pretty notions too
In moral mischief.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Your desert in this
Exceeds all other service, and shall bind me
Both to acknowledge, and reward.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Sweet madam!
Think me but worth your favour, i would creep
Upon my knees to honour you, and for every
Minute you lend to my reward, I'll pay
A year of serviceable tribute.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You
Can compliment.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Thus still she puts me off,
Unless i speak the down right word, she'll never
Understand me, a man would think that creeping
Upon one's knees were English to a lady. Enter Alex.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: How is't Jack? Pleasures attend you madam,
How does my plant of honour?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Tis Alexander.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Rich and glorious!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: 'Tis Alexander the great.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: And my Bucephalus
Waits at the door.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Your case is altered sir.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: I cannot help these things, the fates will have it,
'Tis not my land does this.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: But thou hast a plough
That brings it in.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Now he looks brave and lovely.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Well 〈◊〉 my gallant Macedonian.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Madam you gave your nephew for my pupil,
I read but in a tavern, if you'll horror us,
The bear at the bridge foot shall entertain you,
A drawer is my Ganymede, he shall skink
Brisk nectar to us, we will only have
A dozen partridge in a dish, as many pheasants,
Quails, cocks and godwits, shall come marching up
Like the trained band, a fort of sturgeon
Shall give most bold defiance to an army,
And triumph o'er the table.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Sir, it will
But dull the appetite to hear more, and mine
Must be excused, another time I may
Be your guest.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: 'Tis grown in fashion now with ladies,
When you please I'll attend you; Littleworth
Come Frederick.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: We'll have music, I love noise,
We will out roar the Thames and shake the bridge boy. Ex.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Madam I kiss your hand, would you would think
Of your poor servant, flesh and blood is frail,
And trouble some to carry without help.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: A coach will easily convey it, or
You may take water at strand bridge.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: But I
Have taken fire.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: The Thames will cool.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: But never quench my heart, your charity
Can only do that!

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I will keep it cold
Of purpose,

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Now you bless me, and I dare
Be drunk in expectation.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I am confident
He knows me not, and I were worse than mad
To be my own betrayer, here's my husband. Enter born.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Why, how now Aretina? What alone?
The mystery of this solitude? my house
Turn desert o'the sudden, all the gamesters
Blown up? Why is the music put to silence?
Or ha' their instruments caught a cold, since we
Gave 'em the last heat? I must know thy ground
Of melancholy.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You are merry, as
You came from kissing Celestina.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I
Feel her yet warm upon my lip, she is
Most excellent company, I did not think
There was that sweetness in her sex, I must
Acknowledge 'twas thy cure to disenchant me
from a dull husband to an active lover,
With such a lady, I could spend more years,
Than since my birth my glass hath run 〈◊〉 minutes,
And yet be young, her presence has a spell
To keep off age, she has an eye would strike
Fire through an adamant.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I have heard as much
Bestowed upon a dull faced chambermaid
Whom love and wit would thus commend, true beauty
Is mocked when we compare thus, itself being
Above what can be fetched to make it lovely,
Or could our thoughts reach some thing to declare
The glories of a face, or body's elegance,
That touches but our sense, when beauty spreads
Over the soul, and calls up understanding
To look when thence is offered, and admire,
In both I must acknowledge Celestina
Most excellently fair, fair above all
The beauties I ha' seen, and one most worthy
Man's love and wonder.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Do you speak Aretina,
This with a pure sense to commend, or is't
The mockery of my praise

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: Although it shame
Myself, I must be just, and give her all
The excellency of women, and were I
A man.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I know not with what loss,
I should attempt her love, she is a piece
So angellically moving, I should think
Frailty excused to dote upon her form,
And almost virtue to be wicked with her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What should this mean? this is no jealousy,
Or she believes I counterfeit, I feel
Something within me, like a heat, to give
Her cause, would Celestina but consent,
What a frail thing is man, it is not worth
Our glory to be chaste, while we deny
Mirth and converse with women, he is good
That dares the tempter, yet corrects his blood. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have told you all my knowledge since he is pleased
To invite himself he shall be entertained,
and you shall be my witnesses.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who comes with him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir William Sentlove, that prepared me for
The honourable encounter, I expect
His lordship every minute. Enter Sentlove.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: My lord is come. Enter lord. Hairecut.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: He has honoured me.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: My lord your periwig is awry ▪

sp.speaker: Lo
sp.l: You sir —While Hairecut is busy about his hair, Sentlove goes to Celestina.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: You may guess, at the gentleman that's with him.
It is his barber, madam, d'ye observe
And your ladyship want a shaver.

sp.speaker: Hai.
sp.l: She is here sir,
I am betrayed Sentlove your plot, I may
Have opportunity to be revengedExit.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: She in the midst.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: She's fair, I must confess,
But does she keep this distance out of state.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Though I am poor in language to express
How much your lordship honours me, my heart
Is rich and proud in such a guest, I shall
Be out of love with every air abroad,
And for his grace done my unworthy house,
Be a fond prisoner, become anchorite,
And spend my hours in prayer, to reward
The blessing, and the bounty of this presence.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Though you could turn each place you move in ▪ to
A temple, rather than a wall should hide
So rich a beauty from the world, it were
Less want to lose our piety and your prayer,
A throne were fitter to present you to
Our wonder, whence your eyes more worth than all
They look on, should chain every heart a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: 'Twas pretty well come off.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: By your example
I shall know how to compliment, in this
You more confirm my welcome.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I shall love
My lips the better, if their silent language
Persuade your lordship but to think so truly.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You make me smile madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I hope you came not
With fear that any sadness here should shake
One blossom from your eye, I should be miserable
To present any object should displease you.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You do not madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: As I should account
It no less sorrow, if your lordship should
Lay too severe a censure on my freedom.
I wonot court a prince against his justice,
Nor bribe him with a smile to think me honest,
Pardon my lord this boldness, and the mirth
That may flow from me, I believe my father
Thought of no winding sheet when he begotten me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: She has a merry soul, it will become
Me ask your pardon madam for my rude
Approach so much a stranger to your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not my lord so much stranger to my knowledge,
Though I have but seen your person afar oft,
I am acquainted with your character,
Which I have heard so often, I can speak it.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You shall do me an honour.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If your lordship will
Be patient.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: And glad to hear my faults.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That as your conscience can agree upon 'em,
However if your lordship give me privilege,
I'll tell you what's the opinion of the world.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You cannot please me better.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You're a lord
Born with as much nobility as would
Divided serve to make ten noble men
Without a herald, but with so much spirit,
And height of soul, as well might furnish twenty.
You are learned, a thing not compatible now
With native honour, and are master of
A language that doth chain all years, and charm
All hearts, where you persuade, a wit so flowing
And prudence to correct it, that all men
Believe they only meet in you, which with
A spacious memory make up the full wonders;
To these you have known valour, and upon
A noble cause, know how to use a sword
To honour's best advantage, though you were none;
You are as bountiful, as the showers that fall
Into the springs green bosom; as you were
Created lord of fortune, not her steward;
So constant to the cause, in which you make
yourself an advocate, you dare all dangers,
And men had rather you should be their friend,
Than justice or the bench, bound up together.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But did you hear all this.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And more my lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Pray let me have it madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To all these virtues, there is added one,
(Your lordship will remember when I name it,
I speak but what I gather from the voice
Of others) it is grown to a full fame
That you have loved a woman.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: But one madam?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes many, give me leave to smile my lord,
I shall not need to interpret in what sense,
But you have showed yourself right honourable,
And for your love to ladies have deserved,
If their vote might prevail a marble statue,
I make no comment on the people's text.
My lord I should be sorry to offend.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You cannot madam, these are things we owe
To nature for.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And honest men will pay
Their debts.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: If they be able, or compound.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: She had a hard heart, would be unmerciful,
And not give day to men so promising,
But you owed women nothing,

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Yes I am
Still in their debt, and I must owe them love,
It was part of my character.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: With your lordship's
Pardon I only said, you had a fame
For loving women, but of late men say
You have against the imperial laws of love,
Restrained the active flowings of your blood,
And with a mistress buried all that is
Hoped for in love's succession, as all beauty
Had died with her, and left the world benighted!
In this you more dishonour all our sex
Than you did grace a part, when everywhere
Love tempts your eye to admire a glorious harvest,
And everywhere as full blown ears submit
Their golden heads, the laden trees bow down
Their willing fruit, and court your amorous tasting.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I see men would dissect me to a fiber,
But do you believe this?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It is my wonder!
I must confess a man of nobler earth
Then goes to vulgar composition,
Born and bred high, so unconfined, so rich
In fortunes, and so read in all that sum
Up humane knowledge, to feed gloriously,
And live at court, the only sphere wherein
True beauty moves, nature's most wealthy garden,
Where every blossom is more worth, than all
The Hesperian fruit, by jealous dragon watched
Where all delights do circle appetite,
And pleasures multiply by being tasted,)
Should be so lost with thought of one, turn ashes.
There's nothing left my lord that can excuse you,
Unless you plead, what I am ashamed to prompt
Your wisdom too?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: What that?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That you have played
The surgeon with yourself

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And am made eunuch.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It were much pity.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Trouble not yourself,
I could convince your fears with demonstration
That I am man enough, but knew not where
Until this meeting beauty dwelled; the court
You talked of must be where the Queen of love is,
Which moves but with your person, in your eye
Her glory shines, and only at that flame
Her wanton boy doth light his quickening torch.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nay now you compliment, I would it did
My lord for your own sake.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You would be kind,
And love me then.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My lord I should be loving
Where I found worth to invite it, and should cherish
A constant man.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then you should me madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But is the ice about your heart fallen off,
Can you return to do what love commands?
Cupid thou shall have instant sacrifice.
And I dare be the priest.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your hand, your lip,
Now I am proof 'gainst all temptation.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: Your meaning my good lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I that have strength
Against thy voice and beauty, after this
May dare the charms of womankind, thou art
Bella Maria unprofaned yet,
This magic has no power upon my blood.
Farewell madam, if you durst be the example
Of chaste as well as fair, thou wert a brave one.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I hope your lordship means not this for earnest,
Be pleased to grace a banquet.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Pardon madam.
Will Sentlove follow, I must laugh at you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My lord I must beseech you stay, for honour
For her whose memory you love best.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And by that virtue you have now professed,
I charge you to believe me too, I can
Now glory, that you have been worth my trial,
Which I beseech you pardon, had not you
So valiantly recovered in this conflict,
You had been my triumph, without hope of more
Than my just scorn upon your wanton flame;
Nor will I think these noble thoughts grew first
From melancholy, for some female loss,
As the fantastic world believes, but from
Truth, and your love of innocence, which shine
So bright in the two royal luminaries
At court, you cannot lose your way to chastity,
Proceed, and speak of me as honour guides you. Exit lord.
I am almost tired, come ladies we'll beguile
Dull time, and take the air another while. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: But hath sir Thomas lost five hundred pounds
Already?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: And five hundred more he borrowed,
The dice are notable devourers madam,
They make no more of pieces, than of pebbles,
But thrust their heaps together to engender,
Two hundred more the caster cries this gentleman,
I am w'ee. I ha' that to nothing sir, the caster
Again, 'tis covered, and the table too,
With sums that frighted me, here one speaks out,
And with a martyr's patience, smiles upon
His money's executioner, the dice,
Commands a pipe of good tobacco, and
I'th smoke on't vanishes; another makes
the bones vault o'er his head, swears that ill throwing
Has put his shoulder out of joint calls for
A bone setter that looks to'th box, to bid
His master send him some more hundred pounds,
Which lost, he takes tobacco, and is quiet;
Here a strong arm throws in, and in, with which
He brusheth all the table, pays the rooks
That went their smelts a piece upon his hand,
Yet swears he has not drawn a stake this seven year.
But I was bid make haste ▪ my master may
Lose this five hundred pound ere I come thither. Exit.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: If we both waste so fast, we shall soon find
Our state is not immortal, some thing in
His other ways appear not well already. Enter sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye tortoises, why make you no more haste,
Go pay to'th master of the house that money,
And tell the noble gamesters, I have another
Superfluous thousand pound, at night I'll visit 'em.
D'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes and please you.

sp.speaker: Bor
sp.l: Do't ye drudges,
Ta ra ra — Aretina.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You have a pleasant humour sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What should a gentleman be sad?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You have lost.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: A transitory sum, as good that way
As another.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Do you not vex within for't?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I had rather lose a thousand more, than one
Sad thought come near my heart fort, vex for trash,
Although it go from other men like drops.
Of their life blood, we lose with the alacrity,
We drink a cup of sack, or kiss a mistress,
No money is considerable with a gamester,
They have souls more spacious than Kings, did two
Gamesters divide the empire of the world
They'd make one throw for't all, and he that lost
Be no more melancholy, than to have played for
A morning draught, vex a rich soul for dirt,
The quiet of whose every thought is worth
A province:

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: But when dice have consumed all;
Your patience will not pawn for as much more.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Hang pawning, sell outright, and the fears over.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Say you so? I'll have another coach tomorrow
if there be rich above ground.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I forgotten
To bid the fellow ask my jeweller,
Whether the chain of diamonds be made up,
I will present it to my lady Bellamour,
Fair Celestina.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: This gown i have worn
Six days already, it looks dull, I'll give it
My waiting woman, and have one of cloth
Of gold embroidered, shoes and pantables
Will show well of the same.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I have invited
A covey of ladies, and as many gentlemen
Tomorrow to the Italian ordinary,
I shall have rarities, and regalli as
To pay for madam, music, wanton songs,
And tunes of silken petticoats to dance to.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: And tomorrow have I invited half the court
To dine here, what misfortune 'tis your company
And ours should be divided? after dinner
I entertain 'em with a play.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: By that time
Your play inclines to the epilogue, shall we
Quit our Italian host, and whirl in coaches,
To the douch magazine of sauce, the stillyard,
Where deal, and Bacharach, and what strange wine else,
They dare but give a name too in the reckoning
Shall flow into our room, and drown Westphalias,
Tongues, and anchovies, like some little town
Endangered by a sluice, through whose fierce ebb
We wade and wash ourselves into a boat,
And bid our coachmen drive their leather tenements
By land, while we sail home with a fresh tide
To some new rendezvous.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: If you have not
Pointed the place, pray bring your ladies hither,
I mean to have a ball tomorrow night,
And a rich banquet for 'em, where we'll dance
Till morning rise, and blush to interrupt us.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Have you no ladies i'th next room, to advance
A present mirth? What a dull house you govern?
Farewell, a wife's no company — Aretina,
I've summed up my estate, and find we may have
A month good yet ▪

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And i do rather
be lord one month of pleasures, to the height
And rapture of our senses, than be years,
Consuming what we have in foolish temperance,
Live in the dark, and no fame wait upon us,
I will live so, posterity shall stand
At gaze when I am mentioned.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: A month good,
And what shall be done then.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I'll over sea,
And trail a pike, with watching, marching, lying
In trenches, with enduring cold, and hunger,
And taking here and there a musketshot,
I can earn every week four shillings madam,
And if the bullets favour me to snatch
Any superfluous limb, when I return
With good friends, I despair not to be entold
Poor knight of Windsor; for your course madam,
No doubt you may do well, your friends are great,
Or if your poverty, and their pride cannot
Agree, you need not trouble much invention,
To find a trade to live by, there are customers,
Farewell, be frolic madam, if I live
I will feast all my senses, and not fall
Less than a Phaeton from my throne of pleasure,
Though my estate flame like the world about me.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: 'Tis very pretty. Enter Decoy.
Madam Decoy.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: What melancholyExit.
After so sweet a night's work? Have not I
Showed myself mistress of my art.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: A lady.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: That title makes the credit of the act
A story higher, you've not seen him yet,
I wonder what he'll say.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: He's here.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: Bear upEnter Alexander and Frederick.
My little Myrmidon, does not Jack Littleworth
Follow?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Follow? He fell into the Thames
At landing.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The devil shall dive for him
Ere I endanger my silk stockings for him,
Let the watermen alone, they have drags and engines,
When he has drunk his julip, I shall laugh
To see him come in pickled the next tide.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: He'll never sink, he has such a cork brain.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: Let him be hanged or drowned all's one to me,
Yet he deserves to die by water, cannot
Bear his wine credibly.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Is not this my aunt?

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: And another handsome lady, I must know her.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: My blood is rampant too, I must court somebody ,
As good my aunt, as any other body.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Where have you been cousin?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: At the bridge,
At the bear's foot, where our first health began
To the fair Aretina, whose sweet company
Was wished by all, we could not get a lay,
A tumbler, a device, a bona roba
For any money, drawers were grown dull;
We wanted our true firks and our vagaries;
When were you in drink aunt?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Do not ladies
Play the good fellows too? there's no true mirth
Without 'em, I have now such tickling fancies,
That doctor of the chair of wit, has read
A precious lecture, how I should behave
Myself to ladies, as now for example.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Would you practise upon me?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I first salute you,
You have a soft hand madam, are you so
All over?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Nephew.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Nay you should but smile,
And then again I kiss you; and thus draw
Off your white glove, and start to see your hand
More excellently white, I grace my own
Lip with this touch, and turning gently thus,
Prepare you for my skill in palmistry,
Which out of curiosity no lady
But easily applies too, the first line
I took with most ambition to find out,
Is Venus' girdle, a fair semicircle
Enclosing both the mount of sol and Saturn,
If that appear, she's for my turn, a lady
Whom nature has prepared for the career,
And Cupid at my elbow, I put forward,
You have this very line, aunt.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: The boy's frantic.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You have a couch or palate, I can shut
The chamber door, enrich a stranger when
your nephew's coming into play.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Are you so coy to your own flesh and blood?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Here take your playfellow, I talk of sport,
And she would have me marry her.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Here's Littleworth. Enter Littleworth wet.
Why how now tutor?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: I ha' been fishing.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: And what ha' you caught?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: My belly full of water.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ha ha, where's thy rapier?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: My rapier's is drowned,
And I am little better, I was up byth' heels,
And out came a tun of water beside wine.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Thas made thee sober.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Would you have me drunk
With water?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I hope your fire is quenched by this time.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: It is not now, as when your worship walked
By all the taverns Jack, dry as a bone.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You had store of fish under water Jack.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: It has made a poor John of me.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I do not think but if we cast an angle
Into his belly, we might find some pilchards.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: And boiled by this time, dear madam a-bed .

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Carry but the water spaniel to a grassplot
Where he may roll himself, let him but shake
His ears twice in the sun, and you may grind him
Into a posset.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Come thou shalt to my bed
Poor pickerel.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Alas sweet gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: I have ill luck, and I should smell by this time,
I am but new ta'en I am sure, sweet gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Your servant.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Pray do not pluck off my skin,
It is so wet, unless you have good eyes
You'll hardly know it from a shirt.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: He has sack enough, and I may find his humour. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And how is't with your ladyship? you look
Without a sunshine in your face.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You are glorious
In mind and habit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ends of gold and silver.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Your other clothes were not so rich, who was
Your tailor sir?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: They were made for me long since,
They have known but two bright days upon my back,
I had a humour madam to lay things by,
They will serve two days more, I think I ha' gold enough
To go to'th mercer, I'll now allow myself
a suit a week as this, with necessary
Dependences, beaver, silk stockings, garters,
And roses in their due conformity,
Boots are forbid a clean leg, but to ride in,
My linen every morning comes in new,
The old goes too great bellies.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You are charitable.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I may dine w'ee sometime, or at the court
To meet good company, not for the table,
My clerk o'th kitchens here, a witty epicure,
A spirit that to please me with what's rare
Can fly a hundred mile a day to market,
And make me lord of fish and foul, I shall
Forget there is a butcher, and to make
My footmen nimble, he shall feed on nothing
But wings of wildfowl.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: These ways are costly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Therefore I'll have it so, I ha' sprung a mine.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You make me wonder sir, to see this change
Of fortune, your revenue was not late
So plentiful.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Hang dirty land and lordships,
I wonot change one lodging I ha' got
For the chamber of London.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Strange of such a sudden,
To rise to this estate, no fortunate hand
At dice could lift you up so, for 'tis since
Last night, yesterday, you were no such monarch.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: There be more games than dice.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: It cannot be
A mistress, though your person is worth love,
None possibly are rich enough to feed
As you have cast the method of your riots,
A Princess, after all her jewels must
Be forced to sell her provinces.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Now you talk
Of jewels? What do you think of this?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: A rich one.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You'll honour me to wear't, this other toy
I had from you, this chain I borrowed of you,
A friend had it in keeping, if your ladyship
Want any sum, you know your friend and Alexander ▪

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Dare you trust my security.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: There's gold,
I shall have more tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You astonish me, who can supply these?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A dear friend I have,
she promised we should meet again i'th morning.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Not that I wish to know
More of your happiness, than I have already
Heart to congratulate, be pleased to lay
My wonder.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Tis a secret.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Which I'll die
Ere I'll betray.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You have always wished me well,
But you shall swear not to reveal the party.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I'll lose the benefit of my tongue.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Nor be
Afraid at what I say, what think you first
Of an old witch, a strange ill favoured hag
That for my company last night, has wrought
This cure upon my fortune? I do sweat
To think upon her name.

sp.speaker: Are
sp.l: How sir a witch?

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: I would not fright your ladyship too much
At first, but witches are a kin to spirits,
The truth is — nay if you look pale already,
I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Sir I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: If you have
But courage then to know the truth, I'll tell you
In one word, my chief friend is the devil.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What devil? How I tremble.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: Have a heart,
'Twas a she devil too, a most insatiate
Abominable devil with a tail
Thus long.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Goodness defend me, did you see her?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No 'twas i'th dark, but she appeared first to me
I'th likeness of a bedlam, and was brought
I know not how, nor whither, by two goblins,
More hooded than a hawk.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: But would you venture
Upon a devil?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I for means.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: How black
An impudence is this? But are you sure
It was the devil you enjoyed.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Say nothing,
I did the best to please her, but as sure
As you live, 'twas a hellcat.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: D'ye not quake?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I found myself the very same in i'th morning,
Where two of her familiars had left me. Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord is come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No words,
As you respect my safety, I ha' told tales
Out of the devil's school, if it be known
I lose a friend, 'tis now about the time
I promised her to meet again, at my
return I'll tell you wonders, not a word. Exit.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: 'Tis a false glass, sure I am more deformed,
What have I done, my soul is miserable. Enter lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I sent you a letter madam.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You expressed
Your noble care of me my lord. Enter Bornwell, Celestina.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Your lordship
Does me an honour.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Madam I am glad
To see you here, I meant to have kissed your hand
Ere my return to court.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir Thomas has
Prevailed to bring me to his trouble hither.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You do him grace.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Why what's the matter madam?
Your eyes are tuning lachrimae.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: As you
Do hope for heaven withdraw, and give me but
The patience of ten minutes.

sp.speaker: Born.
sp.l: Wonderful!
I wonot hear you above that proportion,
She talks of heaven, come, where must we to counsel?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You shall conclude me when you please.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I follow.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What alteration is this? I that so late
Stood the temptation of her eye, and voice,
Boasted a heart, above all licentious flame,
At second view turn renegade, and think
I was too superstitious, and full
Of phlegm not to reward her amorous courtship
With manly freedom.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I obey you sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I'll wait upon your lordship presently.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: She could not want a cunning to seem honest
When I neglected her, I am resolved,
You still look pleasant madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have cause
My lord, the rather for your presence, which
Hath power to charm all trouble in my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I must translate that compliment and owe
All that is cheerful in myself to these
All quickening smiles, and rather than such bright
Eyes should repent their influence upon me,
I would release the aspects, and quit the bounty
Of all the other stars; did you not think me
A strange and melancholy gentleman
To use you so unkindly.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Me my lord?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I hope you made no loud complaint, I would not
be tried by a jury of ladies.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: For what my lord?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I did not meet that noble entertainment,
You were late pleased to show me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I observed
No such defect in your lordship, but a brave
And noble fortitude.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A noble folly
I bring repentance fort, I know you have
Madam a gentle faith, and wonot ruin
What you have built to honour you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: If you can love I'll tell your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have a stubborn soul else.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You are all
Composed of harmony.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What love d'ye mean ▪

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That which doth perfect both, madam you have heard
I can be constant, and if you consent
To grace it so, there is a spacious dwelling
Prepared within my heart for such a mistress.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Your mistress, my good lord?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why my good lady?
Your sex doth hold it no dishonour
To become mistress to a noble servant
In the now court, Platonic way, consider
Who 'tis that pleads to you, my birth, and present
Value can be no stain to your embrace,
But these are shadows when my love appears,
Which shall in his first miracle return
Me in my bloom of youth, and thee a virgin,
When I within some new Elysium
Of purpose made and meant for us, shall be
In every thing Adonis, but in his
Contempt of love, and court thee from a Daphne
Hid in the cold rind of a bashful tree,
With such warm language, and delight, till thou
Leap from that bays into the Queen of love,
And pay my conquest with composing garlands
Of thy own myrtle for me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What's all this?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Consent to be my mistress Celestina,
And we will have it springtime all the year,
Upon whose invitations when we walk,
The winds shall play soft descant to our feet,
And breathe rich odours to repure the air,
Green bowers on every side shall tempt our stay,
and violets stoop to have us tread upon 'em.
The red rose shall grow pale, being near thy cheek,
And the white blush o'ercome with such a forehead,
Here laid, and measuring with ourselves some bank,
A thousand birds shall from the woods repair.
And place themselves so cunningly, behind
The leaves of every tree, that while they pay
As tribute of their songs, thou shalt imagine
The very trees bear music, and sweet voices
Do grow in every arbour, here can we
Embrace and kiss, tell tales, and kiss again,
And none but heaven our rival.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: When we are
Weary of these, what if we shift our paradise?
And through a grove of tall and even pine,
Descend into a valley, that shall shame
All the delights of Tempe, upon whose
Green plush the graces shall be called to dance
To please us, and maintain their fairy revels,
To the harmonious murmurs of a stream
That gently falls upon a rock of pearl,
Here doth the nymph forsaken echo dwell,
To whom we'll tell the story of our love,
Till at our surfeit and her want of joy,
We break her heart with envy, not far off
A grove shall call us to a wanton river,
To see a dying swan give up the ghost,
The fishes shooting up their tears in bubbles
That they must lose the genius of their waves,
And such love linsey woolsey, to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You chide me handsomely, pray tell me how
You like this language.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Good my lord forbear.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You need not fly out of this circle madam,
These widows so are full of circumstance,
I'll undertake in this time I ha' courted
Your ladyship for the toy, to ha' broken ten,
Nay twenty colts, virgins I mean, and taught 'em
The amble, or what pace I most affected.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You're not my lord again, the lord I thought you.
And I must tell you now, you do forget
yourself and me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You'll not be angry madam.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: Nor rude, though gay men have a privilege,
It shall appear, there is a man my lord
Within my acquaintance, rich in worldly fortunes,
But cannot boast any descent of blood,
Would buy a coat of arms.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: He may, and legs booted and spurred to ride into the country.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But these will want antiquity: my lord
The seal of honour, what's a coat cut out
But yesterday to make a man a gentleman?
Your family as old, as the first virtue
That merited an escutcheon, doth owe
A glorious coat of arms, if you will sell now
All that your name doth challenge in that ensign,
I'll help you to a chapman, that shall pay
And pour down wealth enough fort.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Sell my arms?
I cannot madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Give but your consent,
You know not how the state may be inclined
To dispensation, we may prevail
Upon the herald's office afterwards.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I'll sooner give these arms to'th hangman's axe,
My head, my heart, to twenty executions
Than sell one atom from my name.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Change that,
And answer him would buy my honour from me.
Honour that is not worn upon a flag
Or pennon, that without the owner's dangers,
An enemy may ravish, and bear from me,
But that which grows and withers with my soul,
Beside the body's stain, think, think my lord
To what you would unworthily betray me,
If you would not for price of gold, or pleasure,
(If that be more your idol) lose the glory
And painted honour of your house — I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Enough to rectify a satire's blood,
Obscure my blushes here. Enter Sentlove and Hairecut.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Or this or sight with me,
It shall be no exception that I wait
Upon my lord, I am a gentleman,
You may be less and bea knight, the office,
I do my lord is honest sir, how many
such you have been guilty of, heaven knows.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: 'Tis no fear of your sword, but that I would not
Break the good laws established against duels.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Oft with your periwig, and stand bare.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: From this
Minute I'll be a servant to thy goodness,
A mistress in the wanton sense is common,
I'll honour you with chaste thoughts, and call you so.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: I'll study to be worth your fair opinion.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Sent love, your head was used to a covering,
Beside a hat, when went the hair away.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I laid a wager my lord with Hairecut,
Who thinks I shall catch cold, that I'll stand bare
This half hour.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Pardon my ambition
Madam, I told you truth, I am a gentleman,
And cannot fear that name is drowned in my
Relation to my lord.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I dare not think so.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: From henceforth call my service duty madam,
That pig's head that betrayed me to your mirth,
Is doing penance for't.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Why may not I
My lord begin a fashion of no hair.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Do you sweat sir William.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Not with store of nightcaps.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Heaven has dissolved the clouds that hung upon
My eyes, and if you can with mercy meet
A penitent, I throw my own will off,
And now in all things obey yours, my nephew
Send back again to'th college, and myself
To what place you'll confine me.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Dearer now
Than ever to my bosom, thou shalt please
Me best to live at thy own choice, I did
But fright thee with a noise of my expenses,
The sums are safe, and we have wealth enough,
If yet we use it nobly? My lord — madam,
Pray honour tonight .

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I beg your presence,
And pardon.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I know not how my Aretina
May be disposed tomorrow for the country.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: You must not go, before you both have done
Me honour to accept an entertainment,
Where I have power, on those terms I'm your guest.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You grace us madam.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Already
I feel a cure upon my soul, and promise
My after life to virtue, pardon heaven,
My shame yet hid from the world's eye.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Sweet madam. Enter decoy.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not for the world be seen here, we are lost,
I'll visit you at home; but not to practise
What she expects, my counsel may recover her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Where's madam? pray lend me a little money,
My spirit has deceived me, Proserpine
Has broke her word.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Do you expect to find
The devil true to you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Not too loud.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: I'll voice it
Louder, to all the world your horrid sin,
Unless you promise me religiously,
To purge your foul blood by repentance sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Then I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Not while I have power
To encourage you to virtue, I'll endeavour
To find you out some nobler way at court
To thrive in.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Do't, and I'll forsake the devil,
And bring my flesh to obedience; you shall steer me,
My lord — your servant.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You are brave again.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Madam your pardon.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Your offence requires
Humility.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Low as my heart. Sir Thomas
I'll sup with you, a part of satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Our pleasures cool, music, and when our ladies
Are tired with active motion, to give
Them rest in some new rapture to advance
Full mirth, our souls shall leap into a dance.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
